turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Cutrer, could I ask you two questions that you covered in your brief?

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Number one, would you agree or disagree that the management would have standing under 14(e) that's one question, and the other question, I want you to refresh my recollection.
Why is the scienter relevant to our problems here in view of the fact that liability is a given?
That covers your --

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: Your second question was the first one I wanted to take up, Justice Stevens; so if I could, I'd like to answer that first.

When I said that the issue of violation was not in the case, even as to 14(e), I should have mentioned that as our certiorari petition itself states and as the questions present state, we raise the question of whether damages are recoverable under 14(e) absent scienter in the Hochfelder sense.
So that is an issue in the case.
Could you repeat your first question again, Justice Stevens?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Okay.
The first question is whether management of the other contestant would have standing under 14(e), and logically I'm ...

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: Right.

We would concede that the corporation as distinguished from management interested in its perks, its salaries or fees in case it got thrown out, but that the corporation has standing certainly to sue for an injunction to protect the target shareholders and perhaps even to sue for damages for the corporation, which would protect the target shareholders.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Now, in your counterclaim in the District Court, was that the same position you took there?
Was it --

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: Piper.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it wasn't yours; rather, the Piper individuals took the position, I guess, that they had standing, didn't they?
Was there not a counterclaim?

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: There was a counterclaim by Bangor Punta, which was a counterclaim once Chris-Craft had sued us; but our answer to Bangor Punta -- it was a stipulated answer -- specifically raised the question of what we've been calling here their standing to sue, whether there was liability for damages.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But then if you should admit that management would have standing in a contest like this, doesn't that make it sort of a one-sided standing rule, that one side has standing, but the other does not?
That's what troubles me a little bit about it.

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: I was speaking of the management having standing to sue the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: To sue for the corporation.

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: -- tender offeror.
In this case, of course, we have two tender offerors.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: But let's say one tender offeror for an injunction or to recover damages perhaps for the benefit of the target shareholders who are all members of that corporation.
And I did say in answer to a question from Justice Stewart earlier that perhaps even a competing tender offeror would have standing to sue for an injunction to prevent injury to the shareholders.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right, I understand that.

turn.speaker: lloyd_n_cutler
turn.label: Mr. Lloyd N. Cutler
turn.text: But the test, as I think the Chief Justice’s opinion in Rondeau makes very clear, is, can you show some injury to the shareholders.

And while I'm on that point and you have further questions, Justice Stevens, while it is true, of course, that some of the exchanging Piper shareholders owned Chris-Craft stock, it would seem to me, number one, that their injury is not of an injury of the kind we need consider here, because the principal violation is one relating to the Bangor tender offer, the one they didn't accept.
They accepted the other offer.

Moreover, given a case in which some of the target shareholders are on one side of the damage and some are on the other side, Congress might very well have left that particular issue alone and said no damage remedy, just as the District Court really did here.
I'd like to come next to the question of whether the 14½% which Mr. Liman says were involved in the two violations was decisive.

You have an express finding on that from the District Court that after both of those violations at the time that the preliminary injunction was denied that neither party has gained control and both are in a position to do so.
In fact, the Court of Appeals, when it was affirming that finding, said each side had an equal opportunity to gain control.

What the Court of Appeals did was to misinterpret Mills -- and this is a point I don't have time for now, which will be covered in our brief -- to presume both that the target shareholders would have rejected the offer, and of course Mills invokes no presumptions and turns only on the point that the target shareholders were entitled to a clean and accurate prospectus or proxy, whether or not it would have affected their offer; and secondly, he made the presumption, which Mills certainly doesn't authorize because it said damages should be awarded only to the extent they can be proven, that the violation caused Chris-Craft to lose its opportunity for control.
Is that all the time I have?
Thank you, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
